did.abstract: This is a collection of records of various community organizations fighting the redevelopment of Washington Square Park and the surrounding area. Their efforts included closing the park to traffic, fighting the construction of NYU's library and university housing, and the creation of more parkland. The collection contains letters and statements of opposition from local community groups and individuals. Also included are government documents and New York University publications relating to the potential redevelopment.
did.langmaterial: The documents in the collection are in English.

eventgrp.event: New York University announces plans to redevelop Washington Square Park Southeast area.
Washington Square Park Committee announces its plan to fight the project.
Washington Square Park converts from being open to all traffic to only being open to bus traffic.
Washington Square Park completely closed to traffic.
New York University reveals design of library on Washington Square South.
New York University asks the City Planning Commission to review proposal of campus expansion, including the library.
Community Planning Commission holds public hearing on the project.
New York University's Bobst Library completed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection is comprised of materials relating to Washington Square Park's history from 1952 to 1966. The issues that these papers cover are the traffic through the square, New York University's new library and housing project, parkland and park use. The collection consists of letters and statements of opposition, community organizations' records opposing the redevelopment, government documents and New York University publications. Also included are letters to Shirley Hayes, a local community leader who was instrumental in getting the park closed to traffic.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Most of the collection is arranged by organization. The letters from individuals and to Shirley Hayes are arranged chronologically. The papers are arranged into the following series:
Series II: New York University Publications
Series IV: Letters and Statements of Opposition

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at The New-York Historical Society
relatedmaterial.p: Further material on Washington Square Park can be found in the Records of the Washington Arch and in the Shirley Hayes Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains a variety of materials from various community organizations that supported the Washington Square Park and Greenwich Village community. Most of these community organizations supported the closing of the park to traffic and not building the New York University library. Materials include newsletters, letters, minutes, reports, petitions, and meeting flyers.

did.unittitle: Series II: New York University Publications

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains publications produced by New York University. The materials included are chancellor's reports, student newspapers, newsletters, reports, a map, and newspapers clippings. This part of the collection gives the university's prospective on their projects.

did.unittitle: Materials Regarding Redevelopment of Washington Square Park

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains documents from New York City agencies and New York State agencies. The materials included are letters from the agencies, reports, meeting minutes, calendars, and law amendments. The letters show what individual members of the local government thought about the projects.

did.unittitle: Series IV: Letters and Statements of Opposition

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains letters and statements of opposition from individuals, mostly from the Greenwich Village and Washington Square Park areas. It also includes letters written to Shirley Hayes. Hayes was influential in getting the park closed to traffic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains newspaper clippings, notes, and a map. The clippings do not include New York University newspapers. It is unclear who took the notes, but they do provide information on the redevelopment of the square. The map is of the proposed street changes to what was then known as West Broadway (La Guardia Place now).
